Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants are Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Evidence_Assessment: RPD panel assessed legislative and judicial measures in Mexico
Applicants presented evidence of corruption and violence
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate lack of adequate state protection
Credibility_Factor: Applicants' fear of persecution from abusive ex-partner considered credible but insufficient without proof of state failure
Legal_Rule: Test for state protection is adequacy, not effectiveness
Democratic states presumed capable of protection unless strong contrary evidence
Procedural_Issue: Alleged errors in assessment of state protection and ignored evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: RPD adequately considered personal circumstances and evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Judicial mechanisms for domestic violence victims
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration and refugee protection regime
Applicant_Challenge: RPD erred in finding adequate state protection in Mexico
Legal_Rule_Source: Canadian jurisprudence on refugee status and state protection
Defendant_Response: State of Mexico has sufficient legal framework to protect victims of domestic violence
Legal_Provision: Section 97, IRPA (persons in need of protection)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Particular social group: women in Mexico who cannot access state protection
Governing_Rule: Adequacy of state protection test in refugee claims
